Authors: Sujatha Mulpuri, SURESH G, HELAN B THOMAS, Pushpa H.D.
Title:
Association of Golovinomyces cichoracearum and Podosphaera
xanthii in causing powdery mildew disease of niger (Guizotia abyssinica
L.F. Cass) in India
Keywords:
Anamorph, Asteraceae, Mixed infection, rDNA-ITS, Erysiphe,
Oilseed
Abstract:
Powdery mildew is one of the important diseases in niger
(Guizotia abyssinica L.F. Cass) in India and Ethiopia. The pathogen
inciting the disease is reported as Erysiphe cichoracearum and
Sphaerotheca sp., but the fungal species has not been studied in detail
to confirm the pathogen. In the present investigation, powdery mildew
infection observed on niger in Hyderabad, India was analysed using
morphological, molecular, and rDNA-ITS sequence analysis. Results based
on anamorph characteristics, amplification products with genus and
species-specific primers of Erysiphales and sequence analysis
unequivocally indicated mixed infection of Podosphaera xanthii and
Golovinomyces cichoracearum in the samples analysed regardless of the
season and location. Variation in reaction to powdery mildew was
observed in Indian and USDA collection and infection was high in the
Ethiopian accessions as compared to the Indian varieties. Unlike most
other crops, control (uninfected) samples of niger that were sterilized
showed amplification with universal primers and sequence analysis
indicated similarity with ITS sequences of nuclear ribosomal DNA of the
family Asteraceae. This constitutes the first report of morphological
and molecular analysis of mixed infection of powdery mildew pathogen in
niger.
